column1: Are you ready to begin the survey?
column2: Do you have any experience in analyzing, processing, or managing software logs?
column3: Are you familiar with the following data protection regulations and standards? (Select all that apply)
column4: Based on the above examples, which of the following attributes do you consider sensitive in software logs? Each row includes an example after the colon (:) (Select all that apply)
column5: Have you ever anonymized log data?
column6: When you want to share software logs, which attributes do you anonymize? Each row includes an example after the colon (:) (Select all that apply)
column7: Why do your responses regarding which attributes are sensitive (the question on page 4) differ from those you actually anonymize (the question on page 6) in software logs? (Select all that apply)
column8: What factors influence your decision to anonymize certain log attributes? (Select all that apply)
column9: Which anonymization techniques do you primarily use for log data? (Select all that apply)
column10: How much do you believe anonymization impacts the usefulness of the data?
column11: How challenging do you find balancing anonymization with the need to preserve the utility of log data?
column12: How effective do you believe your current anonymization practices are in protecting sensitive information?
column13: How effective do you believe your current anonymization practices are in preserving utility?
column14: How efficient do you believe your current anonymization practices are in terms of computation cost and time?
column15: Can you share any strategies or best practices you use to maintain data utility while anonymizing logs?
column16: What challenges do you face when applying anonymization techniques to software logs?
column17: Do you have any additional comments, suggestions, or insights you'd like to share regarding log anonymization practices or this survey?
column18: Which best describes your role in the organization?
column19: How many years of experience do you have?
column20: In which industry does your organization operate?
column21: What is the approximate size of your organization?

column4: IP address: 192.168.1.1, Mac address: 5c:50:15:4c:18:13, Host name: hollerith.hrz.tu-chemnitz.de, This can be sensitive ( rhost=ec2-52-80-34-196.cn-north-1.compute.amazonaws.com.cn) Do note data can be sensitive without being PII. For it to be PII, it needs to be related. Eg. mac address + location is high sensitive PII
column17: Look at log anonymization APIs/tools that are commonly used. Lots of enterprise code contains legacy code with very custom redaction loggers. Financial information sometimes is difficult to redact - eg. ACH transactions require lots of PII to be put in a text file un-redacted and transferred via an API/stored as a copy. Same with payment gateways. In real world, efforts are also put in isolating logging in a manner that in all the logs do not divulge  PII data (eg firstname is acceptable, but first, last + DoB together is PII)

column4: NONE, This should not be a binary question and depends on context of the environment, community, secondary actions (e.g. Re-identification, linking, correlation)
column6: IP address: 192.168.1.1, Mac address: 5c:50:15:4c:18:13, File path: /user/root/rand/_temporary/part-00742, URL: http://cs-www.bu.edu/lib/pics/bu-logo.gif, IDs: Process ID, Thread ID, Job ID, Node ID, Application ID, Device ID, Host name: ec2-52-80-34-196.cn-north-1.compute.amazonaws.com.cn, Request response size, Request response time, Environmental data: temperature ambient=33, Again, this depends on context.  If you collect heights of people in a community and there is a person that is 7' tall, their height then becomes identifiable.  Need to consider the ISO std for deidentification ISO/IEC 27559:2022
column7: I anonymize only those attributes that are required by company policies or regulations., Anonymizing certain sensitive attributes could compromise the utility of the logs, so I avoid doing so., There are technical limitations or challenges in anonymizing certain sensitive attributes., Audit logs are anonymized to mitigate privacy risks to individuals and to prevent improper correlations.  Additional security controls are also applied to prevent misuse of audit logs curated from a variety of sources.  Audit logs are pseudonymized and encrypted by default.  Policies and tooling are in place to prevent misuse of audit materials.  Given the amount of audit materials that we, a hyperscale cloud provider, must address, audit review very automated.
column8: Legal compliance, Risk of re-identification, Impact on data utility, Customer requirements, company policies align and exceed legal compliance for the many jurisdictions where we conduct business.
column9: Aggregation, Pseudonymization - Note that there may be "break glass" scenarios where reidentification is required.
column15: Pseudonymizing logs is important to address privacy in certain contexts.  We are fortunate that for many analytics (e.g. Product improvement) aggregation is a meaningful approach to   deriving value from audit.  Certainly from a reliability perspective, there is often no need to examine outliers.  There is a need, from time to time, to be able to be specific for outliers (e.g. for criminal investigations or cyber incidents).  It's important to be able to have a structured approach to reidentify materials.  We also provide individuals and organizations with the ability to select the amount of diagnostic data that they share.
column16: Education and perception of our customers.  Many individuals, organizations and regulators have an imprecise view of hyperscale cloud operations and the need to operate at an exa-scale in a hostile environment.  The traditional view of a human reviewing fan-fold paper is over 25 years old, but the mindset seems to remain.  The idea that individuals would casually data browse seeking interesting interactions is almost as futile as searching for the word "the" in all english text.
column17: The anonymization of data in logs in wholly dependent on the use case for the audit information.  If it is used for security investigations, there needs to be a mechanism to reidentify actors (legal discovery, cyber threats, fraud).  If it is used for realtime security decisions (conditional access, end point protection) then additional anonymization may be afforded GUID, PUID.  If it is being used for bulk decision making (reliability, feature analysis, product improvement) then greater anonymity can be afforded

column3: GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation), PIPEDA (Personal Information Protection and Electronic Documents Act), NS, AB, SK, BC access to info and privacy legislation
column4: IP may be sensitive or public, other elements such as IDs, date and time, and user actions associated with a log may be sensitive depending on the context in which its used, how it is connected to a person or represents a person
column17: Defining PI or PHI  requires interpretation of context. A log that demonstrates action associated with a person, while factual, may be PI if it demonstrates failure to comply with legislation or policy, and that action is being viewed in association with understanding a person's action. Suggest reviewing regulatory body decisions (OIPC) regarding defining PI. Risk of triangulation, and re-identification should also be considered when making log data available for secondary purposes.

column16:
Legal complaince while maintaining unique identifies without introducing a reverse identification threat vector, maintaining SLAs, software frameworks (e
g., Spark) not built for privacy first, the EC (European Commission) complaince requires back and forth with a long turnaround time
column17: IMO companies should build for privacy first, not minimal complaince. Minimal complaince causes a bunch of thrash (e.g., engineering time, impacted timelines, frozen or shutdown products, reevaluations of changes by Product).

column15: Using enterprise-wide key management / tokenization to ensure that protected / anonymized / deidentified logs can be aggregated across multiple systems from different points in time by a SIEM while maintaining referential integrity to support analytics and ultimately real-time alerting without risk of exposure should the SIEM be attacked.
column16: Parsing is always a challenge and the incidence of false positives (values that appear as sensitive values but are actually not) is key.  Also, the ability to find and protect any PII / PHI that may exist in the message payload (text).
column17: Suggest investigating the tight coupling between a SIEM and its backend protection engine.  One such example is ArcSight ESM Logger coupled with Voltage SecureData.
